notes: Unified security theory synthesized from 9 operational security documents, 3 active waivers, RFC-0020 HSI constraints, and cross-domain invariant analysis.
Every SEC-LAW traces to operational source documents. Every operational control traces to at least one SEC-LAW.
Scale invariance validated: each law holds identically from 1 agent to 10^9 agents; only leverage changes.
When this document conflicts with RFC-0020 or SECURITY_POLICY, those are the source of truth and this document MUST be updated.

doc.title: Unified Security Theory for Agent-Native Holonic Systems

thesis.one_line: Security in agent-native holonic systems is the mechanical enforcement of containment boundaries through proof-carrying authority, where every effect is receipt-evidenced, every delegation is strictly narrowing, and every ambiguity resolves to denial.

SEC-THESIS-01.statement: Authority is never ambient — it is carried, narrowed, and verified at every boundary crossing.
implications: All side effects flow through daemon-mediated, capability-gated paths.
Delegation cannot widen authority across any dimension.
Verification cost is bounded and first-class.

SEC-THESIS-02.statement: Effects without receipts do not exist in the system's epistemic model — unproven is indistinguishable from non-existent.
implications: Receipt bundles are the sole evidence of authoritative state transitions.
Replay verification is always possible for any claimed effect.
Batch verification amortizes proof cost without weakening guarantees.

SEC-THESIS-03.statement: Ambiguity is adversarial — unknown, stale, or unverifiable state defaults to denial, not warning.
implications: Fail-closed is the universal default; fail-open requires explicit waiver.
Freshness is a machine-checkable policy, not best-effort.
Stop uncertainty propagates denial within bounded latency.

SEC-THESIS-04.statement: Security primitives are scale-invariant — the same containment contract applies at recursion depth 1 and 10^9; only the consequence magnitude changes.
implications: Verification economics must be O(log n) or better, never O(n).
Batch attestation and Merkle proof structures are mandatory, not optimization.
A law that needs special modes at higher scale reveals a missing, more fundamental law underneath.

frame_a_boundary_centric.organizing_principle: Security is the geometry of trust boundaries — what crosses, at what granularity, under what proof obligation.
frame_a_boundary_centric.key_insight: Every security failure is a boundary violation: either something crossed that shouldn't have (injection, leakage), or something that crossed lacked proof (ambient authority, forged identity), or the boundary's freshness contract was stale (replay, rollback).
frame_a_boundary_centric.strongest_contribution: Clarifies that SEC-LAW-01 (no ambient authority), SEC-LAW-07 (digest-first), and SEC-LAW-08 (dual-lattice) are all boundary geometry laws — they constrain what geometric properties the trust boundary enforces.

frame_b_economics_centric.organizing_principle: Security is a verification economics game — the defender's cost to verify must be bounded while the attacker's cost to forge must be unbounded.
frame_b_economics_centric.key_insight: Every security primitive has a verification cost. At exabyte scale, any O(n) verification becomes a DoS vector. The defender's advantage comes from amortized batch verification (O(1) signature checks per batch + O(K log B) hashing) while the attacker must forge each proof independently.
frame_b_economics_centric.strongest_contribution: Clarifies that SEC-LAW-05 (bounded verification), SEC-LAW-09 (pull-budget anti-entropy), and SEC-LAW-10 (continuity economics) are verification economics laws — they bound defender cost under both proof validation and adversarial synchronization pressure.

frame_c_lattice_centric.organizing_principle: Security is a lattice algebra — authority, taint, classification, and delegation form partially ordered sets where safety is meet-closure and violations are lattice breaks.
frame_c_lattice_centric.key_insight: The PermeabilityReceiptV1 meet operator (componentwise intersection across all authority dimensions) is a lattice meet. The dual-lattice taint/classification enforcement is a product lattice. Strict-subset delegation is monotone narrowing in the authority lattice. All three are instances of the same algebraic structure.
frame_c_lattice_centric.strongest_contribution: Clarifies that SEC-LAW-03 (strict-subset delegation), SEC-LAW-08 (dual-lattice), and SEC-LAW-02 (receipt authority) share algebraic structure — they are all lattice-meet-closure requirements.

parallel_framings.recombination: The unified theory uses boundary geometry as the primary organizing frame (what crosses boundaries), lattice algebra as the structural invariant (how authority and taint compose), and verification economics as the scaling constraint (how proof cost bounds). Each law is annotated with its framing provenance.

normative_language.MUST: Mandatory requirement. Violation is a security defect and release-blocking.
normative_language.SHOULD: Allowed only with documented rationale and compensating controls bound to a ticket.
normative_language.MAY: Permitted only on non-authority-bearing paths; never grants authority or weakens fail-closed semantics.

cryptography_profile.algorithm_agility_rule: New algorithms are additive allowlist changes gated by compatibility tests and signed governance approval.

evidence_retention.immutability_requirement: Evidence stores are append-only and content-addressed.

explicit_assumptions.statement: JCS canonicalization is deterministic across implementations and versions pinned by canonicalizer vectors.
CAS objects are immutable and retrieval by hash is collision-resistant under approved hash policy.
Trust roots for identity and policy are distributed through authenticated channels with revocation support.
HTF temporal anchors are available for authority-bearing decisions; wall-clock is never authoritative.
Ledger ordering for receipt anchors is monotonic and replay-detectable within declared rollback window bounds.
CSPRNG entropy for signing keys, session keys, and nonces remains above policy floor with continuous health checks.
Policy-root mutation workflows enforce dual approval and monotone policy-root epochs across all authority-bearing cells.

security_laws.name: No Ambient Authority
security_laws.statement: No agent, holon, or process holds authority by default. All authority is explicitly delegated through capability-gated, daemon-mediated paths. Side effects without capability delegation are mechanically impossible, not merely prohibited.

cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In a pure capability system, the only way to obtain authority is to receive it from an entity that already holds it. No 'ambient' authority exists.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Biological cells have no default access to anything outside their membrane — all signaling requires specific receptor-ligand binding.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Agent-native holonic systems are structurally isomorphic to capability systems: holons are objects, PermeabilityReceiptV1 is the capability token, and the daemon mediates all authority flow.

operationalization.desc: All side effects (tool calls, file I/O, network, governance) flow through the daemon process; capsule processes have no direct OS-level authority.
subrules: **Capsule isolation:** Capsule processes run under capability-restricted sandbox profiles.
**Tool gating:** Every tool invocation is validated against CapabilityManifestV1 scope before execution.
**Context firewall:** Reads outside the ContextPackManifest allowlist are denied by default.

operationalization.desc: Cross-holon authority is admitted only via PermeabilityReceiptV1; no other authority admission path exists.

security_laws.scale_invariance: Identical at depth 1 (single capsule → daemon) and depth 10^9 (billion-holon federation). The daemon mediation boundary is recursive: each holon's daemon enforces the same contract regardless of nesting depth.

security_laws.name: Receipt-Backed Authority
security_laws.statement: Every authoritative state transition produces a machine-readable receipt stored in CAS and linked via the ledger. Effects without receipts are treated as non-existent. Receipt authentication uses direct signature or AuthoritySealV1 over Merkle batch roots.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Cryptographic commitment schemes and authenticated data structures (Merkle 1979)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: A commitment scheme binds a party to a value such that the commitment can be verified without revealing the value, and the party cannot change the value after commitment. Receipts are commitments to effects.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Enzyme-substrate reactions produce measurable products (receipts); the cell's metabolic state is the sum of verified products, not claimed intentions.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Agent-native effects are stochastic and potentially adversarial. Receipt commitment provides the same non-repudiation guarantee as cryptographic commitments: once committed, the effect is bound.

operationalization.desc: Every successful gate pass, tool execution, and governance decision produces a receipt stored in CAS.
subrules: **Direct signature:** Single-issuer receipts carry Ed25519 signature over canonical receipt bytes.
**AuthoritySealV1:** Batch receipts carry Merkle root signature + per-receipt inclusion proof.
**Ledger anchoring:** All receipts are linked to a ledger sequence position.

operationalization.desc: Receipt authentication resolves the full trust chain: receipt → EpisodeEnvelope → CapabilityManifest → PermeabilityReceiptV1.
subrules: **Proof bytes bounded:** Decoder bounds enforced before acceptance.
**Verification failures emit defects:** Cannot silently downgrade.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ authoritative_transition t: ∃ receipt(t) ∧ cas_stored(receipt(t)) ∧ ledger_linked(receipt(t)) ∧ signature_valid(receipt(t))

security_laws.scale_invariance: At depth 1, each receipt is individually signed. At depth 10^9, AuthoritySealV1 batch verification provides O(1) signature checks per batch + O(K log B) hashing. The receipt semantic contract is identical; only the verification amortization changes.

security_laws.name: Strict-Subset Delegation
security_laws.statement: Every delegation narrows authority across ALL dimensions simultaneously: scope, budgets, stop predicates, attestation floor, input taint, output classification, expiry, and fanout caps. The meet operator on AuthorityVectorV1 enforces componentwise intersection — no dimension can widen.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Lattice theory and capability security (principle of least authority, POLA)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In a bounded lattice, the meet of two elements is their greatest lower bound. Authority delegation as lattice meet guarantees monotone narrowing: child ≤ parent across every dimension.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Cellular differentiation narrows potential: a stem cell can become anything, but each differentiation step irreversibly constrains what the cell can become. Authority delegation is irreversible narrowing.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: AuthorityVectorV1 is a product lattice over multiple ordered dimensions. The meet operator computes componentwise minimum/intersection, which is exactly the lattice meet. This algebraic structure guarantees that no delegation path can escalate authority.

operationalization.desc: The meet(parent, child) operator computes componentwise intersection across all AuthorityVectorV1 dimensions.
subrules: **risk_tier_ceiling:** min(parent, child)
**capability_manifest:** strict_subset(parent, child)
**budgets:** componentwise_min(parent, child)
**stop_condition:** strengthened (child stop is stricter)
**attestation_floor:** max(parent, child) — attestation requirements only increase
**taint_floor:** max(parent, child) — taint requirements only increase
**classification_ceiling:** min(parent, child) — output classification only narrows
**expiry:** intersection(parent, child) — time window only shrinks
**fanout_caps:** componentwise_min(parent, child)

operationalization.desc: Missing or unverifiable delegation artifacts cause denial, not fallback to ambient authority.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ delegation(parent, child): meet(parent.authority, child.authority) = child.authority ∧ child.authority ≤ parent.authority

security_laws.scale_invariance: The meet operator is the same lattice operation whether applied once (depth 1) or recursively through 10^9 levels. Each application narrows, so the deepest child has the most constrained authority. The algebraic guarantee is depth-independent.

security_laws.name: Fail-Closed Under Ambiguity
security_laws.statement: When the security state is unknown, stale, ambiguous, or unverifiable, the system denies actuation. Fail-open requires an explicit, time-bounded waiver with audit trail. 'Warn and continue' is not a valid security posture for authority-bearing paths.

cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In safety-critical systems, unknown state is treated as unsafe state. The system transitions to a known-safe configuration (denial) rather than proceeding under uncertainty.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: The immune system's default response to unknown antigens is inflammatory rejection, not tolerance. Tolerance must be explicitly learned (thymic selection). The cost of false negatives (infection) exceeds false positives (autoimmune response).
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Agent-native systems operate under stochastic, potentially adversarial conditions. The asymmetry between missed-attack cost (unbounded damage) and false-denial cost (bounded delay) makes fail-closed the rational default.

operationalization.desc: Any security-relevant check that returns unknown, timeout, parse-error, stale, or unverifiable results in denial.
subrules: **Identity ambiguity:** Unverifiable identity → deny actuation.
**Freshness ambiguity:** Stale governance/identity heads → deny Tier2+ actuation.
**Stop-state ambiguity:** Unknown stop state → deny actuation within 250ms.
**Contract ambiguity:** Mismatched episode envelope → deny admission.

operationalization.desc: Fail-open behavior requires explicit waiver (WVR-*) with bounded duration, named ownership, compensating controls, and ticket binding.
subrules: **Time-bounded:** Waiver duration MUST be <= 30 days and extension count MUST be <= 1.
**Ownership:** Every waiver names owner, approver, and ticket_ref with security sign-off.
**Compensating controls:** Every waiver declares at least one active compensating control with measurable verification.
**Scoped:** Waivers apply to specific control IDs, not blanket relaxation.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ security_check c: (c.result ∈ {unknown, stale, ambiguous, unverifiable}) → actuation_denied(c) ∨ valid_waiver(c)

security_laws.scale_invariance: Fail-closed is a local property enforced at each boundary crossing. It does not require global coordination. At 10^9 agents, each individual boundary independently denies on ambiguity — the guarantee composes by construction.

security_laws.name: Bounded Verification Economics
security_laws.statement: Verification cost is first-class and bounded. Identity verification is O(log n) in namespace size. Proof bytes are bounded before acceptance. Batch attestation provides O(1) signature checks per batch. Any O(n) verification path is a denial-of-service vector and MUST be eliminated.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Information theory and authenticated data structures (Merkle trees, sparse Merkle tries)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: Membership proof in an authenticated dictionary of size n requires O(log n) hash computations and O(log n) proof bytes. This is information-theoretically optimal for tree-structured commitments.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: The adaptive immune system uses O(log n)-like antigen recognition via clonal selection and affinity maturation, rather than O(n) exhaustive antibody scanning against every possible pathogen.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: At 10^12 holons, O(n) identity verification (linear registry scan) would require scanning trillions of entries per check. O(log n) directory proof + O(1) signature verification is the only scaling strategy that keeps defender cost bounded while attacker cost remains linear in forgery attempts.

operationalization.desc: Identity verification uses HolonDirectoryHeadV1 + IdentityProofV1 with Merkle/SMT membership proofs.
subrules: **No linear scans:** Registry enumeration is forbidden for verification.
**Proof-carrying:** Identity travels as IdentityProofV1 (certificate chain + directory proof).
**max_proof_bytes:** Directory heads declare explicit proof size bounds.

operationalization.desc: All boundary decoders enforce pre-decode byte bounds and post-decode collection bounds before trust decisions.
subrules: **Pre-decode:** Maximum wire bytes checked before deserialization.
**Post-decode:** Maximum collection element count checked after deserialization.
**Violations fail-closed:** Bound violations are denial, not truncation.

operationalization.desc: High-volume receipts use AuthoritySealV1 with Merkle batch roots for amortized O(1) signature verification per batch.
subrules: **<1% overhead contract:** Additional CPU and network overhead ≤ 1% vs baseline commit path.
**Ledger-anchored roots:** Batch roots are ledger-anchored, not free-floating.

operationalization.desc: Asymptotic claims MUST be backed by explicit numeric bounds enforceable in CI and runtime telemetry.
subrules: **max_decode_bytes_authority_path:** ≤ 262144 bytes before decode.
**max_collection_items_authority_path:** ≤ 10000 elements after decode.
**identity_verification_step_bound:** hash_steps ≤ 4 * ceil(log2(directory_entries)) + 64.
**tier3_plus_cpu_budget:** p99 verification_cpu_ms ≤ 50 for authority-bearing checks.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ verification v: proof_bytes(v) ≤ declared_proof_bound(v) ∧ decode_bytes(v) ≤ policy_decode_bound(v.path) ∧ collection_items(v) ≤ policy_collection_bound(v.path) ∧ hash_steps(v) ≤ 4 * ceil(log2(namespace_size(v))) + 64 ∧ cpu_p99_ms(v.path) ≤ policy_cpu_budget_ms(v.path)

security_laws.scale_invariance: At depth 1, verification is trivially bounded. At depth 10^9, the same O(log n) proof structure applies — only the tree depth grows logarithmically. The <1% overhead contract is scale-invariant by construction: it's a ratio, not an absolute bound.

security_laws.name: Freshness as Machine-Checkable Policy
security_laws.statement: Freshness of identity, governance policy, and stop-state authority is a machine-checkable contract (FreshnessPolicyV1), not best-effort. Tier2+ paths fail closed on stale or unverifiable freshness. Wall-clock timestamps are forbidden as authority input; only HTF-compatible temporal references are valid.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Distributed systems temporal ordering (Lamport 1978, hybrid logical clocks)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In an asynchronous distributed system, wall-clock time cannot be trusted for ordering authority-bearing events. Causal ordering (logical clocks, HLC/HTF) provides the only reliable temporal reference for distributed consensus.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Biological cells use molecular gradients and receptor binding (local, verifiable signals) for temporal coordination, not global time references. Cell-cycle checkpoints verify local state freshness before allowing progression.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Holonic federation is asynchronous and adversarial. Wall-clock reliance enables clock-skew and replay windows captured in TM-CLASS-01. HTF-anchored freshness policies provide the same guarantee as Lamport causality: if event A happened-before event B in the causal order, then A's timestamp < B's timestamp.

operationalization.desc: Each risk tier has explicit staleness thresholds with authority-safe actions only.
subrules: **Tier0/Tier1:** May accept bounded staleness for non-authoritative read-only flows only.
**Tier2+:** MUST fail-closed on staleness; no downgrade path.
**Tier3+:** Stop-state freshness additionally enforced with 250ms deny SLO.

operationalization.desc: Authority-bearing temporal references use HTF boundary IDs, not wall-clock timestamps.
subrules: **EpochSealV1:** Required for cross-cell authority admission on untrusted federation links.
**VDF proof:** Required when anti-rollback confidence cannot be established from signed HTF envelope alone.
**Anti-replay:** Cross-cell admission enforces both trust validity AND temporal validity.

security_laws.scale_invariance: FreshnessPolicyV1 is evaluated locally at each boundary crossing. At depth 10^9, each holon independently checks freshness against its local policy. The policy contract is identical; only the staleness thresholds may vary by risk tier (which is itself a local property).

security_laws.name: Digest-First Boundaries
security_laws.statement: Authority-bearing trust boundary decisions use hashes and selectors rather than raw payloads. Raw payload bytes may cross only into quarantine staging with zero authority effect until digest verification and taint/classification checks succeed. Content is dereferenced from CAS after hash verification.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Content-addressed storage (git, IPFS, Nix store) and communication-avoiding algorithms
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In communication-avoiding algorithm design (Demmel et al.), minimizing data movement (bytes across boundaries) rather than computation is the dominant optimization. Content-addressing achieves this by replacing payload transfer with hash comparison + selective dereference.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: DNA replication uses template-based verification (hash comparison) before synthesizing new strands (payload retrieval). The cell doesn't copy random sequences — it verifies the template hash first.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: At exabyte scale, raw payload propagation across holon boundaries is a bandwidth DoS vector. Digest-first communication reduces cross-boundary traffic to O(hash_size) per item, with payload retrieval only on verified demand.

operationalization.desc: Cross-boundary communication uses content hashes as primary references; payloads are CAS-retrieved after hash verification.
subrules: **EpisodeEnvelopeV1:** Binds all authority via hashes (repo_hash, lockfile_hash, policy_hash, toolchain_hash, manifest_hash, contract_hash, context_hash).
**Receipt pointers:** ReceiptPointerV1 uses receipt_hash + authority_seal_hash + merkle_inclusion_proof.
**Canonicalization:** Deterministic serialization before hashing/signing.

operationalization.desc: Raw payload retrieval from CAS occurs only after the hash has been verified against a trusted authority chain.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ boundary_crossing bc: authority_effect(bc) → payload_source(bc) = cas_dereference(verified_hash(bc)); raw_payload_transfer(bc) → quarantine_only(bc)

security_laws.scale_invariance: Digest-first is more valuable at scale, not less. At depth 1, it's a clean design pattern. At depth 10^9, it's the difference between exabyte bandwidth consumption (raw payloads) and kilobyte hash exchange. The protocol is identical; only the savings magnitude changes.

security_laws.name: Dual-Lattice Integrity and Confidentiality
security_laws.statement: Operations crossing boundaries enforce BOTH an integrity gate (minimum taint level: UNTRUSTED < SANITIZED < VERIFIED < ATTESTED) AND a confidentiality gate (maximum classification level: PUBLIC < INTERNAL < CONFIDENTIAL < RESTRICTED). The two lattices are independent and jointly enforced — satisfying one does not exempt from the other.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Bell-LaPadula (confidentiality) and Biba (integrity) security models; lattice-based access control (Denning 1976)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: Security policy is a lattice homomorphism: subjects and objects carry labels from partially ordered sets, and allowable information flows must respect the order in both confidentiality (no read-up, no write-down) and integrity (no read-down, no write-up) simultaneously.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Cell membranes enforce bidirectional selectivity: lipophilic molecules pass freely (classification check) while charged molecules require channel proteins (integrity/taint check). Both gates must pass for transmembrane transport.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Agent-native systems face both injection attacks (low-taint input reaching high-impact actuators — integrity failure) and leakage attacks (high-classification output reaching low-clearance channels — confidentiality failure). The dual-lattice structure prevents both simultaneously.

operationalization.desc: Input taint propagates monotonically: UNTRUSTED → SANITIZED → VERIFIED → ATTESTED. High-impact actuators require minimum taint level.
subrules: **Prompt injection prevention:** External/untrusted inputs cannot directly drive high-impact actuators.
**Taint propagation:** Labels propagate across tool invocation and summary paths.
**Tier3+ hard-fail:** Hard-fail firewall semantics (terminate/deny) on taint violation.

operationalization.desc: Output classification is bounded: max output classification ≤ delegation ceiling. Logs, errors, and emissions respect classification boundaries.
subrules: **Secret redaction:** Logs routed through SecretRedactor; patterns auto-redacted.
**Emission control:** Boundary emissions enforce classification ceiling.
**No debug leakage:** Sensitive material uses secrecy::SecretString, not String.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ boundary_emission e: taint_level(e.input) ≥ required_taint(e.target) ∧ classification(e.output) ≤ allowed_classification(e.channel)

security_laws.scale_invariance: The dual-lattice is a local check at each boundary. At depth 10^9, each boundary independently enforces both gates. The lattice structure composes by construction — the product of correct local checks is a globally correct flow.

security_laws.name: Pull-Based Anti-Entropy with Budget Bounds
security_laws.statement: Authority synchronization across federation boundaries is pull-only. Byzantine peers cannot force authority admission. Anti-entropy budgets are scoped per episode, cell, and relay. Budget exceedance triggers denial and defect emission, not silent acceptance or degraded processing.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Byzantine fault tolerance and anti-entropy protocols (Demers et al. 1987, Lamport et al. 1982)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In a Byzantine fault-tolerant system, correct nodes must bound the influence of faulty nodes. Pull-based synchronization achieves this: a correct node only accepts data it explicitly requested, bounding the influence of any single peer to the pull budget.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: The innate immune system's complement pathway operates on a pull basis — opsonization (tagging for phagocytosis) requires specific receptor binding, not bulk acceptance of foreign material. Cells actively select what to internalize.
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Federated holonic systems face Byzantine relays that may attempt to flood authority events (spawn storm, history forgery). Pull-based anti-entropy with per-scope budgets bounds the damage any single Byzantine peer can inflict to the pull budget.

operationalization.desc: Relays cannot push authority events to holons. All authority synchronization is initiated by the receiving holon.
subrules: **Episode budget:** Per-episode authority ingestion limit.
**Cell budget:** Per-cell authority ingestion limit.
**Relay budget:** Per-relay authority ingestion limit.

operationalization.desc: Budget exceedance is DENY_ACTUATION_AND_EMIT_DEFECT, not silent degradation.
subrules: **Revocation-wins:** Revocation events take priority in merge semantics.
**Revocation carve-out:** Revocation messages are exempt from ingest denial but remain subject to strict parser and proof-byte bounds.
**Revocation flood guard:** Revocation carve-out is constrained by per-peer token bucket and global revocation parse budget to prevent carve-out abuse DoS.
**Range caps and fanout caps:** Additional structural bounds on anti-entropy sync volume.
**Convergence guarantee:** Revocation-wins semantics preserved despite budget bounds.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ authority_sync s: pull_initiated(s) ∧ ((is_revocation(s) ∧ within_revocation_guardrails(s)) ∨ within_budget(s, scope)) ∧ (budget_exceeded_non_revocation(s) → denied(s) ∧ defect_emitted(s))

security_laws.scale_invariance: Budget bounds are per-scope (episode, cell, relay), which is a local property. At depth 10^9, each holon maintains its own budget counters. The pull-only invariant is enforced at each boundary independently — no global coordination required.

security_laws.name: Stop-as-Governance-Primitive
security_laws.statement: Stop orders are governance primitives, not convenience signals. Capsule processes MUST honor stops within bounded deadlines. Missing or unknown stop state defaults to denial. Tier3+ SLO: stop propagation p99 ≤ 2000ms; denial on uncertainty ≤ 250ms. The stop path is the last line of defense against runaway autonomous execution.

cross_domain_provenance.source_discipline: Safety engineering (IEC 61508 functional safety) and distributed consensus (Raft/Paxos leader deposition)
cross_domain_provenance.transferable_invariant: In functional safety systems, the safety function (emergency stop) has higher priority than the control function (normal operation). The safety function must remain operable even when the control function has failed.
cross_domain_provenance.biological_analog: Apoptosis (programmed cell death) is a governance primitive in multicellular organisms — cells that fail checkpoint verification are killed within bounded time. Defective apoptosis leads to cancer (runaway autonomous execution).
cross_domain_provenance.why_transfers: Agent-native holonic systems face the same runaway risk as biological systems: an agent that ignores stop signals can cause unbounded damage. Stop-as-primitive ensures that governance can always halt execution, even under partition or Byzantine behavior.

operationalization.desc: Stop orders propagate through the holonic hierarchy with bounded latency.
subrules: **Tier3+ p99:** Stop propagation ≤ 2000ms end-to-end.
**Topology bound:** Tier3+ stop overlay diameter MUST be ≤ 4 hops for authority-bearing deployments.
**Uncertainty deny:** Stop uncertainty denial ≤ 250ms.
**Fail-safe kernel boundary:** If stop state is unknown, kernel-boundary deny activates.

operationalization.desc: Stop conditions are bound into EpisodeEnvelopeV1 and AuthorityVectorV1. Stop predicates strengthen under delegation (child stop is stricter than parent stop).
subrules: **DrillReceiptV1:** Chaos/partition drills validate stop-path behavior.
**Defect emission:** Stop SLO violations emit defects and block ratchet promotion.
**RPO/RTO objectives:** Ledger RPO 300s, CAS RPO 900s, policy root RTO 1800s.

verifier.acceptance_predicate: ∀ tier3_plus_holon h: stop_overlay_diameter(h) ≤ 4 ∧ stop_propagation_p99(h) ≤ 2000ms ∧ stop_uncertainty_deny(h) ≤ 250ms ∧ (stop_state_unknown(h) → actuation_denied(h))

security_laws.scale_invariance: Stop propagation scales by bounded-diameter overlay rather than unbounded chain depth. At depth 10^9, Tier3+ authority-bearing topologies remain admissible only when stop overlay diameter is constrained (≤ 4), preserving the same end-to-end 2000ms contract at every scale.

security_principles.name: Principle of Least Authority (POLA)
security_principles.title: Grant the minimum authority necessary for each task
security_principles.formal: ∀ task T, agent A: authority(A, T) = minimal_set(required_capabilities(T))
security_principles.apm2_mapping: CapabilityManifestV1 binds tool-scope to the minimum needed. AuthorityVectorV1 meet operator ensures delegation never widens. EpisodeEnvelopeV1 pins the authority context for the duration of execution.

security_principles.name: Capability Confinement
security_principles.title: Capabilities cannot be forged, stolen, or amplified — only held, delegated (narrowed), or revoked
security_principles.apm2_mapping: PermeabilityReceiptV1 is the sole cross-boundary authority token. It is cryptographically signed and bound to an EpisodeEnvelope. There is no way to construct a valid receipt without holding a signing key that chains to the authority root.

security_principles.name: Defense in Depth
security_principles.title: Multiple independent protection layers so no single failure is catastrophic
security_principles.formal: P(system_breach) = P(∩ layer_i_breach) with layer-coupling measured explicitly; independence is a testable hypothesis, not an assumption
security_principles.apm2_mapping: Sandbox isolation (OS-level) + daemon mediation (process-level) + capability gating (authority-level) + taint checking (data-level) + freshness enforcement (temporal-level). Each layer is independently enforced.

security_principles.name: Non-Repudiation via Commitment
security_principles.title: Once an effect is committed via receipt, neither party can deny it occurred
security_principles.apm2_mapping: Receipt production, CAS storage, and ledger anchoring create a three-layer commitment that provides non-repudiation. AuthoritySealV1 extends this to batch commitments via Merkle roots.

security_principles.name: Asymmetric Cost of Errors
security_principles.title: The cost of a missed attack far exceeds the cost of a false denial
security_principles.formal: E[cost(false_negative)] >> E[cost(false_positive)] → optimal_threshold biased toward denial
security_principles.apm2_mapping: This asymmetry is why fail-closed is the universal default. A missed injection attack can compromise the entire holonic hierarchy. A false denial delays one operation by one retry cycle. The cost ratio justifies aggressive denial under ambiguity.

security_principles.name: Temporal Authority Requires Causal Ordering
security_principles.title: Wall-clock time cannot ground authority decisions in asynchronous distributed systems
security_principles.formal: ∀ authority_decision D: temporal_reference(D) ∈ HTF_boundary_ids ∧ temporal_reference(D) ∉ wall_clock
security_principles.apm2_mapping: HTF boundary IDs provide the causal ordering substrate. FreshnessPolicyV1 uses these, not wall-clock timestamps, as authority input. This prevents TM-CLASS-01 clock-skew/replay vectors and ensures temporal validity is verifiable under partition.

security_principles.name: Revocation Must Win Under Merge
security_principles.title: In any concurrent merge of authority state, revocation takes precedence over grant
security_principles.formal: ∀ merge(state_a, state_b): if revoked(x) ∈ state_a ∧ granted(x) ∈ state_b → merged_state(x) = revoked
security_principles.apm2_mapping: CRDT anti-entropy with revocation-wins semantics. This is critical for stop-path safety: if one branch of the federation has revoked authority while another hasn't received the revocation, the merge must honor the revocation.

security_principles.name: Bidirectional Boundary Selectivity
security_principles.title: Trust boundaries enforce both inbound integrity gates and outbound confidentiality gates
security_principles.formal: ∀ boundary B: gate_in(B) = min_taint_check ∧ gate_out(B) = max_classification_check
security_principles.apm2_mapping: The dual-lattice (taint × classification) is applied at every holon boundary. Inbound: taint must meet minimum for the target actuator. Outbound: classification must not exceed the channel ceiling. Both gates are independently enforced.

security_principles.name: Verification Economics as First-Class Constraint
security_principles.title: The cost of proof verification must be bounded and explicit, not an afterthought
security_principles.formal: ∀ verification V with namespace size n: cost(V) ∈ O(log n) ∧ proof_bytes(V) ≤ declared_bound
security_principles.apm2_mapping: IdentityProofV1 with Merkle directory proofs provides O(log n) verification. AuthoritySealV1 batch verification provides O(1) amortized signature checks. Both have explicit proof byte bounds declared in directory heads.

security_principles.name: Scale Reveals Leverage, Not New Abstractions
security_principles.title: Deepest security primitives are fractal — same contract at every recursion depth
security_principles.formal: ∀ security_law L, recursion_depth d: semantic_contract(L, d) = semantic_contract(L, 1); only leverage(L, d) grows with d
security_principles.apm2_mapping: Every SEC-LAW is stated in terms that hold identically from 1 agent to 10^9 agents. When a law needs special modes at higher scale, that signals a missing, more fundamental law underneath. The meet operator, fail-closed denial, digest-first exchange — all are the same at every depth.

security_mechanisms.name: PermeabilityReceiptV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Sole cross-holon authority entrance. Carries delegated authority vector with meet-operator narrowing.
key_properties: Cryptographically signed authority delegation
Meet operator enforces componentwise narrowing
Binds to EpisodeEnvelopeV1 for anti-replay
Carries full AuthorityVectorV1 (risk tier, budgets, stop, taint, classification, expiry, fanout)

security_mechanisms.name: CapabilityManifestV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Sealed OCAP handles + scopes (paths, patterns, size, network, risk tier) for tool-level authority.
key_properties: Tool-scope binding for each delegated capability
Validated against before every tool invocation
Hash bound into EpisodeEnvelopeV1
Strict-subset of parent manifest under delegation

security_mechanisms.name: AuthoritySealV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Batch receipt authentication via Merkle root signature. Provides O(1) amortized signature verification per batch.
key_properties: Merkle batch root signed by cell authority or quorum
Per-receipt inclusion proofs for individual verification
Ledger-anchored (not free-floating)
<1% CPU and network overhead vs baseline commit path

security_mechanisms.name: EpisodeEnvelopeV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Immutable binding of identity, budgets, stop conditions, pinned snapshots, and authority context for a single episode.
key_properties: Binds: identity, budgets, stop conditions, repo hash, lockfile hash, policy hash, toolchain hash, manifest hash, contract hash, context hash, risk tier, determinism class
All authoritative receipts MUST bind episode envelope hash
Prevents replay and confused-deputy attacks via mismatch detection
Immutable once created — any change requires new episode

security_mechanisms.name: IdentityProofV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: O(log n) identity verification via certificate chain + Merkle directory proof.
key_properties: Bundles: cell certificate hash, holon certificate hash, directory head hash, directory proof, as_of_anchor
O(log n) membership proof in authenticated dictionary
max_proof_bytes declared in directory head for DoS bound
Proof-carrying: identity travels with its proof, no registry lookup needed

security_mechanisms.name: Context Firewall
security_mechanisms.purpose: Hard enforcement of context read boundaries for capsule processes.
key_properties: Reads outside ContextPackManifest allowlist denied by default
Tier3+: hard-fail termination + CapsuleViolation + denial receipt
Prevents covert channels and TOCTOU attacks
Daemon-mediated: capsule cannot bypass via direct I/O

security_mechanisms.name: FreshnessPolicyV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Machine-checkable freshness contract with risk-tiered staleness thresholds and actions.
key_properties: Per-risk-tier staleness thresholds
Staleness actions: Tier0/1 read-only downgrade with bounded lag; Tier2+ deny
HTF-compatible temporal references only
Cross-cell admission enforces both trust AND temporal validity

security_mechanisms.name: SecretRedactor
security_mechanisms.purpose: Mandatory log and artifact redaction for sensitive material.
key_properties: Auto-redacts patterns: *_KEY, *_TOKEN, *_SECRET, *_PASSWORD, cloud/provider prefixes
Applied to runtime logs, API responses, errors, textual channels
Paired with secrecy::SecretString for in-memory protection
Defense-in-depth against confidentiality leakage

security_mechanisms.name: HolonDirectoryHeadV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Authenticated dictionary commitment for O(log n) membership verification and DoS-bounded proof bytes.
key_properties: Cell-scoped directory with monotone epoch
Ledger-anchored root hash (SMT-256 or Patricia trie)
max_proof_bytes: explicit DoS bound
Authority-sealed by policy root key

security_mechanisms.name: EpochSealV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Federation anti-rollback mechanism binding HTF envelope with policy-gated VDF proof requirements.
key_properties: Binds HTF envelope for temporal anchoring
VDF (Verifiable Delay Function) proof required on untrusted links when signed envelope confidence is insufficient
Federation-critical for cross-cell temporal coordination
Prevents rollback attacks where adversary replays old epoch state

security_mechanisms.name: Sigstore Keyless Signing
security_mechanisms.purpose: Eliminate long-lived signing keys from release operations via OIDC → Fulcio → Cosign → Rekor pipeline.
key_properties: GitHub Actions OIDC token → Fulcio short-lived certificate → Cosign ephemeral signing → Rekor transparency logging
Eliminates project-managed long-lived private signing keys in CI release paths
Identity-constrained verification: must match expected repository and workflow
SLSA provenance + SBOM for build-origin claims

security_mechanisms.name: DrillReceiptV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Evidence artifact proving chaos/partition drill execution and stop-path behavior under failure conditions.
key_properties: Records: drill scenario, execution evidence, pass/fail, timing measurements
Drill scenarios: network partition, ledger append latency, CAS unavailability, stop-path degradation
Required for Tier3+ stop-path SLO validation
Provides falsifiable evidence that stop mechanisms work under adversarial conditions

security_mechanisms.name: SessionKeyDelegationV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Bind ephemeral session keys to authenticated delegation context so handshake identities cannot be replayed or transplanted.
key_properties: Session key delegation binds session_public_key to episode_envelope_hash and permeability_receipt_hash
Delegations carry nonce and expiry anchors with strict replay denial
Handshake acceptance requires trust-chain validation plus freshness checks
Session key scope cannot exceed parent capability and risk-tier ceilings

security_mechanisms.name: PolicyRootDualApprovalV1
security_mechanisms.purpose: Prevent insider and single-operator policy-root abuse through dual approval, epoch monotonicity, and anomaly-scored admission.
key_properties: Policy-root mutations require two distinct approvers with disjoint roles
Every accepted mutation increments policy_root_epoch monotonically
Anomaly detection score is evaluated before mutation admission
Mutations emit governance receipts for forensic replay and revocation

security_defects.name: AMBIENT_AUTHORITY_ESCAPE
security_defects.description: A capsule process obtained authority without going through daemon-mediated capability paths.
security_defects.detection: Sandbox profile violation, direct syscall from capsule, tool invocation without manifest match
security_defects.remediation: Strengthen sandbox profile, add missing tool type to mediation layer

security_defects.name: DELEGATION_WIDENING
security_defects.description: A child holon obtained wider authority than its parent in any dimension of AuthorityVectorV1.
security_defects.detection: Meet operator verification: child vector must equal meet(parent, child)
security_defects.remediation: Fix meet operator implementation, add dimension-by-dimension assertion

security_defects.name: SINGLE_LAYER_BYPASS
security_defects.description: A protection layer was bypassed without compensating control from another independent layer.
security_defects.detection: Security audit finding, penetration test result
security_defects.remediation: Add compensating control at adjacent layer

security_defects.name: RECEIPTLESS_PROMOTION
security_defects.description: An authoritative state transition occurred without producing a receipt stored in CAS and linked to the ledger.
security_defects.detection: Ledger audit: transition exists without receipt reference
security_defects.remediation: Block promotion when receipts missing, add receipt production to gate

security_defects.name: FAIL_OPEN_ON_AMBIGUITY
security_defects.description: System proceeded with actuation despite unknown, stale, or unverifiable security state without valid waiver.
security_defects.detection: Audit log showing actuation after ambiguous check result without waiver reference
security_defects.remediation: Convert warn-and-continue to deny, add waiver requirement for any fail-open path

security_defects.name: CONFUSED_DEPUTY
security_defects.description: A lower-privilege entity tricked a higher-privilege entity into performing unauthorized actions.
security_defects.detection: Authority chain audit: verify all tool invocations trace to delegated capabilities
security_defects.remediation: Add confused-deputy prevention check at tool mediation layer

security_defects.name: TEMPORAL_AUTHORITY_VIOLATION
security_defects.description: Authority decision was grounded on wall-clock time instead of HTF-compatible temporal reference.
security_defects.detection: Code review, static analysis for wall-clock in authority paths
security_defects.remediation: Replace wall-clock with HTF boundary ID references

security_defects.name: REVOCATION_SUPPRESSION
security_defects.description: Revocation event was suppressed, delayed, or overridden by a concurrent grant during anti-entropy merge.
security_defects.detection: Anti-entropy audit: verify revocation-wins semantics in all merge operations
security_defects.remediation: Fix merge operator to enforce revocation-wins, add revocation priority test

security_defects.name: PROMPT_INJECTION
security_defects.description: External/untrusted input (low taint) reached a high-impact actuator without taint verification.
security_defects.detection: Taint propagation audit, context firewall violation
security_defects.remediation: Add taint check before high-impact actuator, enforce taint propagation through tool chain

security_defects.name: SECRET_LEAKAGE
security_defects.description: High-classification material was emitted to a channel below its classification ceiling.
security_defects.detection: SecretRedactor pattern match in log/error output, classification audit on boundary emissions
security_defects.remediation: Route logs through SecretRedactor, enforce classification ceiling at emission

security_defects.name: LINEAR_VERIFICATION_COLLAPSE
security_defects.description: Verification cost grew linearly with namespace size or evidence volume, creating a DoS vector.
security_defects.detection: Performance profiling showing O(n) verification, proof byte count exceeding declared bound
security_defects.remediation: Replace linear scan with Merkle proof, enforce max_proof_bytes from directory head

security_defects.name: STOP_PATH_SLO_BREACH
security_defects.description: Stop propagation or uncertainty denial exceeded the Tier3+ SLO (2000ms propagation, 250ms uncertainty deny).
security_defects.detection: DrillReceiptV1 timing measurements, runtime stop-path telemetry
security_defects.remediation: Profile and optimize stop propagation path, implement kernel-boundary fail-safe

security_defects.name: SUPPLY_CHAIN_PROVENANCE_GAP
security_defects.description: Release artifact was admitted without verifiable provenance, identity-constrained signature checks, or transparency log inclusion.
security_defects.detection: Release verification audit detects missing DSSE/SLSA provenance, missing Rekor entry, or workflow/repository identity mismatch
security_defects.remediation: Block release admission until signature, transparency, and provenance checks pass

security_defects.name: WAIVER_GOVERNANCE_DRIFT
security_defects.description: Waiver bypass was executed without required owner/approver/ticket metadata, compensating controls, or policy-bounded duration.
security_defects.detection: Waiver registry audit finds missing required fields, excessive TTL, or inactive compensating controls
security_defects.remediation: Auto-revoke invalid waiver, deny affected authority paths, and require governance re-approval

security_defects.name: FRESHNESS_POLICY_BYPASS_UNDER_PARTITION
security_defects.description: Authority-bearing actuation proceeded under partition despite stale or unverifiable identity/governance/stop freshness.
security_defects.detection: Partition drill or runtime audit shows Tier2+ actuation without valid freshness anchors
security_defects.remediation: Enforce Tier2+ deny-on-stale policy and require HTF/EpochSeal freshness anchors

security_defects.name: CROSS_CELL_ROLLBACK_ACCEPTANCE
security_defects.description: Cross-cell authority admission accepted non-monotone epoch or replayed historical state.
security_defects.detection: Epoch monotonicity check failure, replayed seal reuse, or conflicting epoch acceptance across peers
security_defects.remediation: Reject rollback candidate, quarantine offending peer, and require epoch-seal revalidation

security_defects.name: RESOURCE_BOUND_BYPASS
security_defects.description: Deserializer, proof parser, or anti-entropy path accepted bytes/collections beyond declared bounds.
security_defects.detection: Boundary parser telemetry shows decode/proof bounds exceeded without fail-closed denial
security_defects.remediation: Enforce pre-decode and post-decode bounds before trust decisions and emit defect on violation

security_defects.name: UNTRUSTED_BOOTSTRAP_PAYLOAD_ADMISSION
security_defects.description: Raw bootstrap payload crossed trust boundary and influenced authority decisions without digest-first verification and taint/classification gates.
security_defects.detection: Boundary protocol audit detects direct authority impact from unverified payload bytes
security_defects.remediation: Require quarantine staging plus digest-first promotion before any authority-bearing use

security_defects.name: CANONICALIZATION_DRIFT
security_defects.description: Different canonicalization implementations produced divergent bytes for the same semantic payload, causing signature disagreement or hash mismatches.
security_defects.detection: Cross-implementation canonicalization conformance tests fail or signatures diverge across verifiers for identical input objects
security_defects.remediation: Pin canonicalizer vectors, reject non-conformant serializers, and block authority admission until canonicalization parity is restored

security_defects.name: CAS_IMMUTABILITY_BREACH
security_defects.description: Content-addressed storage returned mutable or hash-inconsistent objects on authority-bearing paths.
security_defects.detection: CAS integrity audit or replay verification detects hash mismatch for previously anchored object IDs
security_defects.remediation: Quarantine CAS tier, invalidate affected receipts, and re-anchor evidence from known-good replicas

security_defects.name: TRUST_ROOT_DISTRIBUTION_FAILURE
security_defects.description: Identity or policy trust roots became unverifiable, stale, or inconsistently distributed across authority-bearing boundaries.
security_defects.detection: Root-set signature checks fail, epoch disagreements emerge across peers, or revocation propagation exceeds policy bounds
security_defects.remediation: Freeze authority-bearing actuation, rotate compromised roots, and require quorum-signed root re-establishment before recovery

security_defects.name: SESSION_KEY_BINDING_BYPASS
security_defects.description: Session authentication accepted a key that was not bound to the active episode envelope and delegation receipt chain.
security_defects.detection: Handshake audit detects missing episode/permeability binding, replayed nonce, or session key scope mismatch
security_defects.remediation: Require SessionKeyDelegationV1 verification, invalidate replayed nonces, and rotate compromised session keys

security_defects.name: DEPENDENCY_POISONING_ADMISSION
security_defects.description: A release or runtime artifact admitted dependencies with unverifiable provenance, disallowed licenses, or known vulnerabilities without an approved waiver.
security_defects.detection: CI/release gate audit shows cargo deny or cargo audit failures bypassed, or dependency drift admitted without security review receipt
security_defects.remediation: Block artifact admission, revert dependency change, and require provenance plus vulnerability clearance receipts

security_defects.name: POLICY_ROOT_GOVERNANCE_BYPASS
security_defects.description: Policy-root mutation was accepted without dual approval, monotone epoch progression, or anomaly-scored admission.
security_defects.detection: Governance audit finds single-approver mutation, epoch rollback, or missing anomaly evidence
security_defects.remediation: Freeze policy-root mutations, revoke unapproved roots, and replay mutations through PolicyRootDualApprovalV1 controls

classes.name: Insider Governance Abuse and Policy-Root Compromise

cross_domain_provenance_summary.note: Each security law has deep roots in established disciplines. This summary maps the complete cross-domain heritage.

disciplines.name: Object-Capability Security
disciplines.founding_works: Dennis & Van Horn 1966, Miller 2006 (E language, capability discipline)
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Authority is held, not ambient; acquired only by delegation from holder or explicit grant from root.

disciplines.name: Cryptographic Commitment Schemes
disciplines.transferable_invariant: A binding commitment prevents the committer from changing the committed value. Receipt-backed authority is a commitment to effects.

disciplines.name: Lattice-Based Access Control
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Security policy as lattice homomorphism: information flow respects partial order in both confidentiality and integrity dimensions.

disciplines.name: Safety Engineering
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Safety function has higher priority than control function. Unknown state is unsafe state. Emergency stop must be operable even under control failure.

disciplines.name: Information Theory and Authenticated Data Structures
disciplines.founding_works: Shannon 1948, Merkle 1979, various sparse Merkle trie designs
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Membership proof in authenticated dictionary of size n requires O(log n) computation. Content-addressing enables deduplication and selective retrieval.

disciplines.name: Distributed Systems Temporal Ordering
disciplines.founding_works: Lamport 1978 (logical clocks), hybrid logical clocks, vector causality
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Wall-clock time is unreliable for ordering in asynchronous distributed systems. Causal ordering provides the only reliable temporal substrate.

disciplines.name: Byzantine Fault Tolerance
disciplines.founding_works: Lamport et al. 1982 (Byzantine Generals), Demers et al. 1987 (epidemic anti-entropy)
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Correct nodes must bound the influence of faulty nodes. Pull-based synchronization bounds attacker influence to the pull budget.

disciplines.name: Biological Immune Systems
disciplines.transferable_invariant: Default rejection of unknown antigens (fail-closed). O(log n)-like recognition via clonal selection. Pull-based phagocytosis via opsonization. Apoptosis as governance primitive.

traceability_matrix.note: Bidirectional traceability: every operational control maps to at least one SEC-LAW, and every SEC-LAW maps to at least one operational control.

waiver_registry.note: Active waivers are exceptional, time-bounded relaxations with explicit accountability. Missing required metadata invalidates the waiver and reverts behavior to fail-closed denial.

active_waivers.title: Transitional governance freshness bypass
active_waivers.justification: Avoid deadlock during temporary governance resolver migration while preserving non-actuation safety.
active_waivers.condition: Only when governance_transitional_resolver=true and no authority-bearing actuation is performed.

active_waivers.title: Deferred pre-actuation budget enforcement
active_waivers.justification: Short-lived migration bridge while replacing deferred budget tracker with pre-actuation enforcement.
active_waivers.condition: Only for non-authority-bearing synchronization when BudgetTracker::deferred() sentinel is present and bound in receipt.

active_waivers.title: Deferred identity proof CAS dereference
active_waivers.justification: Temporary developer-mode accommodation while full CAS dereference reliability fixes are rolled out.
active_waivers.condition: Shape-only hash validation allowed only in developer-mode read-only flows; never for release or authority-bearing actuation.

scale_invariance_validation.note: Each security law is validated for scale invariance: does the semantic contract hold identically from 1 agent to 10^9?

validation.depth_1: Single capsule → daemon mediation. No ambient authority.
validation.depth_10e9: Billion-holon federation → each holon's daemon enforces same contract. Recursive boundary.
Batch verification via AuthoritySealV1. O(1) amortized signature.
validation.verdict: SCALE_INVARIANT — same semantic, better amortization at scale

validation.depth_10e9: Recursive meet through 10^9 levels. Deepest child most constrained.
Each boundary independently denies. No global coordination needed.
validation.verdict: SCALE_INVARIANT — local property, composes by construction

validation.depth_10e9: O(log n) proof depth grows logarithmically. <1% overhead is a ratio.
Each holon independently checks freshness. Policy is local.
Exabyte bandwidth savings vs raw payload. Same protocol, larger savings.
validation.verdict: SCALE_INVARIANT — more valuable at scale, same contract

validation.depth_10e9: Each boundary independently enforces both gates. Product of correct locals.
validation.verdict: SCALE_INVARIANT — local check, global correctness by composition

validation.depth_10e9: Each holon maintains own budget counters. Pull-only is per-boundary.
Bounded-diameter stop overlay keeps end-to-end stop propagation ≤ 2000ms for admitted Tier3+ topologies.
validation.verdict: SCALE_INVARIANT — topology constraints preserve identical end-to-end contract at scale

falsification_criteria.note: For each security law, the falsification criteria specify what evidence would disprove the law's necessity or correctness. This makes the theory scientifically falsifiable, not merely aspirational.

criteria.falsification: Demonstrate a system at 10^6+ agents where ambient authority is safe — i.e., where removing capability gating does not increase exploit surface or blast radius. If ambient authority can be made safe at scale, this law is unnecessary.
Demonstrate that a receipt-free system can provide equivalent non-repudiation and auditability. If effects can be reliably attributed without receipts, this law is unnecessary.
Demonstrate a delegation scheme where widening is safe — i.e., where children can exceed parent authority without creating confused-deputy or escalation vectors.
Demonstrate that fail-open under ambiguity produces better security outcomes than fail-closed when attack probability × damage exceeds denial cost.
Demonstrate O(n) verification that remains viable at 10^12 namespace size without creating DoS vectors.
Demonstrate that wall-clock authority decisions are safe in an asynchronous, adversarial distributed system.
Demonstrate that raw payload exchange at boundaries scales to exabyte volume without bandwidth collapse or injection vectors.
Demonstrate that single-lattice enforcement (integrity only OR confidentiality only) prevents both injection and leakage.
Demonstrate push-based anti-entropy where Byzantine peers cannot force authority admission even without pull-budget bounds.
Demonstrate that advisory stop signals (non-governance-primitive) prevent runaway autonomous execution in adversarial conditions.
